meta.title: Introduction to Financial Accounting
meta.description: Discover the fundamentals of financial accounting from the ground up. This course will teach you to prepare and analyze financial statements. You will also learn to use your understanding of accounting to drive insights into business performance.

default.name: Introduction to Business and Accounting Concepts
default.description: A business is an entity that operates for profit, and accounting is a system that keeps track of a business’s economic events.

default.name: Recording Accounting Transactions

items.name: Process of posting to the ledger accounts
Additional Common Accounting Transactions - Investments by Owners
Additional Common Accounting Transactions - Sales to customers
Additional Common Accounting Transactions - Purchases from vendors
Additional Common Accounting Transactions - Purchase of Assets
Additional Common Accounting Transactions - Depreciation of fixed assets

default.description: A business’s economic events are captured chronologically in a journal and then reorganized by account in the ledgers.

default.name: Financial Statements
default.description: A business’s economic activity for a period is summarized in financial statements that include the income statement, retained earnings statement, and balance sheet.

default.name: Completing the accounting cycle
default.description: The accounting process is cyclical, and once the current cycle is completed, the same recording and reporting activities are repeated in the next period of equal length.

default.name: Comprehensive Problem

items.name: Post the June journal entries to the ledgers
Prepare the June income statement, retained earnings statement and balance sheet
Journalize the closing entries for June
Post the June closing journal entries to the ledgers
Prepare the June post-closing trial balance
Post the July journal entries to the ledgers
Prepare the July income statement, retained earnings statement, and balance sheet
Journalize the closing entries for July
Post the July closing journal entries to the ledgers
Prepare the July post-closing trial balance

default.description: The comprehensive problem covers the complete accounting cycle in terms of interpreting and recording transactions in the journal, posting to ledgers, preparing financial statements, and closing temporary account balances.

default.name: Accounting cycle for a service business – accrual basis
default.description: The accrual basis of accounting recognizes economic events when they take place, regardless of when the related cash transactions occur.

default.name: Accounting cycle for a merchandising business
default.description: A merchandising business buys finished and packaged manufactured products as inventory for sale, marks these items up, and sells them to customers.

default.name: Assets
default.description: Assets are items of value to a business, including things a business owns so it can operate. Common asset classifications are current; long-term; property, plant and equipment; and intangible.

default.name: Liabilities
default.description: Liabilities are claims on a company's assets by people and entities that are not the owners of the business. Simply put, liabilities are debts. Liabilities are classified as either short or long-term.

default.name: Stockholders Equity

items.name: Stockholders' Equity Section of the Balance Sheet

default.description: Stockholders’ equity is the stockholders’ share of ownership of the assets that the business possesses. It includes both the investments that owners have made in the business and the income that the business has generated through its operations.

default.name: Statement of Cash Flows

items.name: Statement of Cash Flows: Direct Method
Statement of Cash Flows: Indirect Method

default.description: The statement of cash flows is a financial statement that shows how changes in balance sheet accounts and income affect cash and cash equivalents in terms of operating, investing, and financing activities.

default.name: Financial Statement Analysis
default.description: Financial statement analysis is the process of reviewing and analyzing a company's financial statements, often times using ratios and other metrics, to make better economic decisions and increase earnings in the future.

default.name: Time Value of Money

items.name: Present Value of Future Cash Flows
Net Present Value & Internal Rate of Return

default.description: The time value of money is the concept that money available now is worth more than the identical amount in the future due to its potential to generate earnings over time.

default.name: Forecasting Cash Flows & Investment Analysis

items.name: Initial Start-up Costs & [Building a Pro Forma Balance Sheet]
Building a Pro Forma Income Statement

default.description: Forecasting is a planning tool that helps management deal with the uncertainty of the future by looking at data from the past, considering the current economic, social, and political status, and analyzing trends.
